sp.l: We excuse you, her imperfections like a torrent
With violence breaks upon me, and at once
Invert and swallow all that's good in me.
Preposterous fates, what mischiefs you involve
Upon a captive prince left to the fury
Of all grand mischief, hath the grandam world
Yet smothered such a strange abortive wonder,
That from her virtues should arise my sin:
I am worse than what's most ill, deprived all reason,
My heart all fiery lust, my soul all treason.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.l: My lord, I fear your health, your changing brow
hath shown so much disturbance, noble Sextus,
Hath not your venturous travel from the camp,
Nor the moist rawness of these humorous night impaired your health?

sp.speaker: Sext.
sp.l: Divinest Lucrece no. I cannot eat.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.l: To rest then, a rank of torches there, attend the prince.

sp.speaker: Sext.
sp.l: Madam, I doubt I am a guest this night
Too troublesome, and I offend your rest.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: This ring speaks for me, that next Collatine you are to me most welcome, yet my lord, thus much presume, without this from his hand, Sextus this night could not have entered here, no, not the King himself, my doors the day time to my friends are free, but in the night the obdure gates are less kind,
sp.l: Without this ring they can no entrance find. Lights for the prince.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: A kiss and so goodnight, nay for your ring's sake deny not that

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.l: Jove give your highness soft and sweet repose.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: And thee the like, repose with soft content,
My vows are fixed, my thoughts on mischief bent.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.l: 'Tis late, so many stars shine in this room,
By reason of this great and princely guest,
The world might call our modesty in question,
To revel thus our husband at the camp,
Hast and to ●est, save in the prince's chamber,
Let not a light appear, my heart's all sadness,
Jove unto thy protection I commit
My chastity and honour to thy keep,
My waking soul I give whilst my thoughts sleep,

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Soft, soft, not too loud, imagine we were now going on the ropes with eggs at our heels, he that hath but a creeking shoe, I would he had a creek in his neck, tread not too hard for disturbing prince Sextus.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: I wonder the P. would ha' none of us stay in his chamber and help him to bed.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: What an ass art thou to wonder, there may be many causes thou knowest the prince is a soldier, and soldiers many times want shift, who can say whether he have a clean shirt on or no? for any thing that we know he hath used staff's acre a late, or hath ta'en a medicine to kill the itch, what's that to us, we did our duty to proffer our service.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: And what should we enter farther into his thoughts, come shall's to bed? I'm as drowsy as a dormouse, and my head's as heavy as though I had a nightcap of lead on:

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: And my eyes begin to glue themselves together, I was till supper was done altogether for your repast, and now after supper I am only for your repose. I think for the two virtues of eating and sleeping, there's never a Roman spirit under the cope, can put me down.

sp.speaker: Myr.
sp.p: For shame what a conjuring and caterwauling keep you here, that my lady cannot sleep: you shall have her call by and by, and send you all to bed with a witness.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Sweet mistress Mirable, we are going.

sp.speaker: Myr.
sp.p: You are too loud: come, every man dispose him to his rest and I'll to mine.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Out with your torch's sir.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Come then, and every man sneak into his kennel

div.stage: Enter Sextus with his sword drawn and a taper light.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Night be as secret as thou art close, as close
As thou art black and dark, thou ominous. Queen
Of tenebrous silence, make this fatal hour,
As true to rape as thou hast made it kind
To murder and harsh mischief: Cinthea mask thy cheek,
And all you sparkling elemental fires,
Choke up your beauties in prodigious fogs,
Or be extinct in some thick vaporous cloud,
Lest you behold my practice: I am bound
Upon a black adventure, on a deed
That must wound virtue, and make beauty bleed.
Pause Sextus, and before thou runnest thyself
Into this violent danger, weigh thy sin,
Thou art yet free, beloved, graced in the camp,
Of great opinion and undoubted hope,
Rome's darling in the universal grace,
Both of the field, and senate: were these fortunes
To make thee great in both, back yet, thy fame
Is free from hazard, and thy style from shame.
Of fate, thou hast usurped such power over man,
That where thou pleadst thy will, no mortal can.
On then, black mischief hurry me the way.
Myself I must destroy, her life betray,
The state of King and subject, the displeasure
Of prince and people, the revenge of noble,
And the contempt of base, the incurred vengeance
Of my wronged kinsman Collatine, the treason
A 'gainst divinest Lucrece: all these total curses
Foreseen not feared upon me Sextus meet,
To make my days harsh so so this might be sweet
No jar of clock no ominous hateful howl
Of any starting hound, no horse rough breathed from the
Of any drowsy groom, wakes this charmed silence, entrails discovered in her bed
And starts this general silence forward still, Lucr.
To make thy lust live, all thy virtues kill.
Here, here, behold! beneath these curtains lies,
That bright enchantress that hath dazed my eyes.
O who but Sextus could commit such waste?
On one so fair, so kind, so truly chaste?
Or like a ravisher thus rudely stand,
To offend this face, this brow, this lip, this hand?
Or at such fatal hours, these revels keep,
With thought once to defile thy innocent sleep,
Save in this breast, such thoughts could find no place,
Or pay with treason her kind hospital grace:
But I am lust-burnt, all bent on what's bad,
That which should calm good thoughts makes Tarquin
Mad. Madam, Lucrece?

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.l: Who's that? o me! beshrew you.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Sweet, 'tis I.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: What I?

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Make room.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: My husband Collatine

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Thy husband's at the camp.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Here is no room for any man save him.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Grant me that grace.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: What are you?

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Tarquin and thy friend, and must enjoy thee.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.l: Heaven such sins defend.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Why do you tremble lady? cease this fear,
I am alone, there's no suspicious ear,
that can bewray this deed: nay start not sweet.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Dream I, or am I full awake? o no!
I know I dream to see prince Tarquin so.
Sweet lord awake me, rid me from this terror,
I know you for a prince, a gentleman,
Royal and honest, one that loves my lord.
And would not wrack a woman's chastity,
For Rome's imperial diadem, o then
Pardon this dream, for being awake I know,
Prince Sextus, Rome's great hope, would not for shame
Provoke his own wrath, or despoil my fame.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: I'm bent on both, my thoughts are all on fire,
Choose thee, thou must embrace death, and desire,
Yet do I love thee, wilt thou accept it?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: If not thy love, thou must enjoy thy foe,
Where fair means cannot, force shall make my way:
By Jove I must enjoy thee.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.l: Sweet lord stay.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: I'm all impatience, violence and rage,
And save thy bed, naught can this fire 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: No, I cannot.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Tell me why?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Hate me, and in that hate first let me die.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: By Jove I'll force thee.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.l: By a god you swear to do a devil's deed: sweet lord forbear
By the same Jove I swear that made this soul,
Never to yield unto an act so foul. Help, help.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: These cushions first shall stop thy breath,
If thou but shriekest: hark how I'll frame thy death.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: The death: I care not, so I keep unstained,
The unceased honour I have yet maintained.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Thou canst keep neither, for if thou but squeechest,
Or lest the least harsh noise jar in my ear,
I'll broach thee on my steel: that done, straight murder
One of thy basest grooms, and lay you both
Grasped arm in arm, on thy adulterate bed.
Then call in witness of that mechal sin,
So shalt thou die: thy 〈…〉,
thy name be odious, thy suspected body
Denied all funeral rites, and loving Colatine
Shall hate thee even in death: then save all this,
And to thy fortunes add another friend,
Give thy fears comfort, and these torments end.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.l: I'll die first, and yet hear me: o as you're noble,
If all your gracious and best generous thoughts
Be not exiled your heart, pity, o pity
The virtues of a woman: mar not that
Cannot be made again: this once defiled,
Not all the ocean waves can purify,
Or wash my stain away, you seek to
That which the radiant splendour of the sun
Cannot make bright again: behold my tears!
O think them pearled drops, destilled from the heart
Of soul chaste Lucrece: think them orators,
To plead the cause of absent Collatine, your friend and kinsman.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Tush, I am obdure.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Then make my name pure: keep my body pure:
O prince of princes, do but weigh your sin,
Think how much I shall lose how small you win.
I lose my honour of my name and blood,
Lost, Rome's imperial crown cannot make good.
You win the world's shame, and all good men's hate,
O who would pleasure, buy at such dear rate?
Nor can you term it pleasure: for what's sweet,
Where force and hate, jar and contention meet?
Weigh but for what 'tis that you urge me still,
To gain a woman's love against her will?
You'll but repent such wrong done a chaste wife,
And think that labour's not worth all your strife.
Curse your hot lust, and say you have wronged your friends,
But all the world cannot make me amends.
I took you for a friend, wrong not my trust,
But let these chaste terms quench your fiery lust.
No, those moist tears, contending with my fire,
Quench not my heat, but make it climb more higher:
I'll drag thee hence.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.l: Oh!

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: If thou raise these cries, lodged in thy slaughtered
Arms some base groom dies,
And Rome that hath thy name admired so long,
Shall blot thy death with scandal from my tongue.

sp.speaker: Lucr
sp.l: Jove guard my innocence.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Lucrece, thar't mine
In spite of Jove and all the powers divine.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: What's o'clock trow? my lord bade me be early ready with his gelding, for he would ride betimes in the morning: now had I rather be up an hour before my time then a minute after, for my lord will be so infinitely angry if I but over sleep myself a moment, that I had better be out of my life then in his displeasure: but soft, some of my lord Collatine's men lie in the next chamber, I care not if I call them up, for it grows towards day: what Pompey, Pompey.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Who is that calls?
'Tis I.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Who's that, my lord Sextus his man? what a pox make you up before day?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: I would have the key of the gate to come at my lord's horse in the stable.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: I would my lord Sextus and you were both in the hayloft, for Pompey can take none of his natural rest amongst you, here's eine ostler, rise and give my horse another peck of hay.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Nay good Pompey help me to the key of the stable.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Well, Pompey was born to do Rome good, in being so kind to the young prince's gelding, but if for my kindness in giving him pease and oats, he should kick me, I should scarce say god a mercy horse: but come, I'll go with thee to the stable.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Nay, weep not sweet, what's done is past recall,
Call not thy name in question, by this sorrow
Which yet is without blemish, what hath passed
Is hid from the world's eye, and only private
Twixt us fair Lucrece, pull not on my head,
the wrath of Rome if I have done thee wrong,
Love was the cause, thy fame is without blot,
And thou in Sextus hast a true friend got,
Nay sweet look up, thou only hast my heart,
I must be gone Lucrece a kiss and part.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Oh!

div.stage: She flings from him and exit.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: No? peevish dame farewell, then be the bruiter
Of thy own shame, which Tarquin would conceals
I am armed against all can come, let mischief frown,
With all his terror armed with ominous fates,
To all their spleens a welcome I'll afford,
With this bold heart, strong hand, and my good sword.

div.stage: Enter Brutus, Valerius Horatius. Arnus, Scevola, Colatine.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p: What so early Valer. and your voice not up yet? thou wast wont to be my lark and raise me with thy early notes.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I was never so hard set yet my lord, but I had ever a fit of mirth for my friend.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p: Prithee let's hear it then whilst we may, for I divine thy music and my madness are both short lived, we shall have somewhat else to do ere long, we hope Valerius.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Jove send it.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Horatius, methinks our wars go not well forward,
Horatius we have greater enemies to bustle with then the
Ardeans if we durst but front them Horatius.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Would it were come to fronting.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p: Then we married men should have the advantage of the bachelor's Horatius, especially such as have revelling wives, those that can caper in the city, while their husbands are in the camp, Collat why are you so sad? the thought of this should not trouble you, having a Luc. to your bedfellow.

sp.speaker: Colla.
sp.p: My lord I know no cause of discontent, yet can not I be merry.

sp.speaker: Aru.
sp.p: I should be frolic if my brother were but returned to the camp, and in good time behold prince Sextus.

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.l: Health to our general.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Thank you.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Will you survey your forces, and give order for a present assault, your soldiers long to be tugging with the Ardeans.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Have you seen Lucretia my lord, how fares she?

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Well, I'll to my tent.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Why how now what's the matter brother?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p: Thank you, no, well, I'll to my tent, get thee to thy tent and a coward go with thee, if thou hast no more spirit to a speedy encounter.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.p: Shall I go after him and know the cause of his discontent?

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.l: Or I my lord?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p: Neither, to pursue a fool in his humour? is the next way to make him more humorous, I'll not be guilty of his folly, thank you! no, before I wish him health again when he is sick of the sullens, may I die, not like a roman, but a runagate.

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.l: Perhaps he's not well.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Well, then let him be ill.

sp.speaker: Valle.
sp.l: The news with this hasty post?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Did nobody see my lord Collatine? o, my lady commends her to you, here's a letter.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Give it me.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Fie upon't, never was poor Pompey so overlaboured as I have been, I think I have spurred my horse such a question, that he's scarce able to wehee or wag his tail for an answer, but my lady bade me spare for no horse flesh, and I think I have made him run his race.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Cousin Collatine the news at Rome?

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.l: Nothing but what you all may well partake: read here my lord.
Dear lord, if ever thou wilt see thy Lucrece,
Choose of the friends which thou affectest best,
And all important business set apart,
Repair to room: commend me to lord Brutus,
Valerius Mutius, and Horatius,
Say I entreat their presence, where my father
Lucretius shall attend them, farewell sweet,
Th'affairs are great, then do not fail to meet.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: I'll thither as I live,

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.l: I though I die,
To room with expeditious wings we'll fly.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: The news, the news, if it have any s●ape
Of sadness, if some prodigy have chanced,
That may beget revenge, I'll cease to chafe,
Vex, martyr, grieve, torture, torment myself,
And tune my humour to strange strains of mirth:
My soul divines some happiness, speak, speak:
I know thou hast some news that will create me
Merry and musical, for I would laugh,
Be new trans-shaped, I prithee sing Valerius that I may air
With thee.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: First tell us what's the project of thy massage?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: My lords, the princely Sextus has been at home, but what he hath done, I may partly mistrust, but cannot altogether resolve you: besides, my lady swore me, that whatsoever I suspected I should say nothing.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.p: If thou wilt not say thy mind, I prithee sing thy mind, and then thou mayst save thine oath.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Indeed I was not sworn to that, I may either laugh out my news or sing am, and so save my oath to my lady.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: How's all at Rome, that with such sad presage,
Disturbed Collatine, and noble Brutus
Are hurried from the camp with Scaevola?
And we with expedition amongst the rest,
Are charged to Rome? speak, what did Sextus there with thy fair mistress?

div.stage: Valerius, Horatius and the clown their catch.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: Did he take fair Lucrece by the tot man?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Toe man.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: I man.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, ha man.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: And further did he strive to go man?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Toe man.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I man.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha man, hafa derry derry derry down a, heigh fa derry dino.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Did he take fair Lucrece by the heel man?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: He'll man.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I man.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Ha ha ha ha man.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: And did he further strive to feel man?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Feel man.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I man.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Ha ha ha ha man, heigh fadery, etc.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Did he take the lady by the shin man?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Shin man.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I man.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Ha ha ha ha man.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Further too would he have been man?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Been man.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I man.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Ha ha ha ha man. Hey fadery. Etc.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Did he take the lady by the knee man?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Knee man.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I man.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Ha ha ha ha man.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Further than that would he be man.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Be man.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I man.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Ha ha ha ha man. heigh fa derie, etc.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Did he take the lady by the thigh man?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Thigh man.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I man.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Ha ha ha ha man.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: And now he came it somewhat nigh man.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Nye man

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I man.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Ha ha ha ha man, heigh fa dery, etc.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But did he do the tother thing man?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Thing man?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I man.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Ha ha ha ha man.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: And at the same had he a fling man.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Fling man.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I man.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Ha ha ha ha man, heigh fadery, etc.

div.stage: A table and chair covered with black.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Mirable.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Is not my father old Lucrecius come yet?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Not yet.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Nor any from the camp?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Neither madam.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Go, be gone, and leave me to the truest grief of heart
That ever entered any matron's breast. Oh!

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Why weep you lady? alas why do you stain
Your modest cheeks with these offensive tears?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Nothing, nay nothing: o you powerful gods,
That should have angels guardent on your throne,
To protect innocence and chastity! o why
Suffer you such inhumane massacre
On harmless virtue? wherefore take you charge,
On sinless souls to see them wounded thus:
With rape or violence? forgive white innocence,
Armour of proof 'gainst sin: or by oppression
Kill virtue quite, and guerdon base transgression?
Is it my fate above all other women?
Or is my sin more heinous than the rest,
That amongst thousands, millions, infinites,
I, only I, should to this shame be born,
To be a stain to women, nature's scorn? o!

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: What ails you madam, troth you make me weep
To see you shed salt tears: what hath oppressed you?
Why is your chamber hung with mourning black?
Your habit sable, and your eyes thus swollen
With ominous tears: alas what troubles you?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I am not, thou didst deceive thy self,
I did not weep, there's nothing troubles me,
But wherefore dost thou blush?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Madam not I.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Indeed thou didst, and in that blush my guilt thou didst betray
How cam'st thou by the notice of my sin?

sp.speaker: Maid●.
sp.l: What sin?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: My blot, my scandal and my shame:
O Tarquin! thou my honour didst betray,
Disgrace no time, no age can wipe away, o!

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Sweet lady cheer yourself, I'll fetch my viol
And see if I can sing you fast asleep ,
A little rest would wear away this passion.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Do what thou wilt, I can command no more,
Being no more a woman, I am now
Devote to death, and an inhabitant
Of th'other world: these eyes must ever weep,
Till fate hath closed them with eternal sleep.

div.stage: Enter Brutus, Collatine, Horatius, Scevola, Valerius one way, Lucretius another way.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Brutus!

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Lucretius!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Father!

sp.speaker: Col,
sp.l: Lucrece!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Collatine!

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: How cheer you madam? how is't with you cousin?
Why is your eye deject and drowned in sorrow?
Why is this funeral black, and ornaments
Of widowhood? resolve me cousin Lucrece.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: How fare you lady?

sp.speaker: Old Luc.
sp.l: What's the matter girl?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Why how is't with you Lucrece, tell me sweet?
Why dost thou hide thy face? And with thy hand
Darken those eyes that were my suns of joy,
To make my pleasures flourish in the spring?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: O me!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Whence are these sighs and tears?

sp.speaker: Sceu.
sp.l: How grows this passion?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Speak lady you are hemmed in with your friends,
Girt in a pale of safety, and environed
And circled in a fortress of your kindred,
Let not those drops fall fruiteles to the ground,
Nor let your sighs add to the senseless wind.
Speak, who hath wrong you?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Ere I speak my woe,
Swear you'll revenge poor Lucrece on her foe.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Be his head arched with gold.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Be his hand armed with an imperial sceptre.

sp.speaker: Old. Luc.
sp.l: Be he great as Tarquin throne in an imperial seat

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Be he no more than mortal, he shall feel
The vengeful edge of this victorious steel.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Then seat you lords, whilst I expose my wrong.
Father, dear husband, and my kinsmen, lords
Hear me, I am dishonoured and disgraced,
my reputation mangled, my renown
Disparaged, but my body, o my body

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: What Lucrece?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Stained, polluted and defiled.
Strange steps are found in my adulterate bed,
And though my thoughts be white as innocence,
Yet is my body soiled with lust burnd sin,
And by a stranger I am strumpeted,
Ravished, enforced, and am no more to rank among the Roman matrons.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Yet cheer you lady, and restrain these tears,
If you were forced, the sin concerns not you,
A woman's born but with a woman's strength: who was the ravisher?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Ay, name him lady, our love to you shall only thus appear
In the revenge that we will take on him.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I hope so lords, was Sextus the King's son.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: How? Sextus Tarquin!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: That unprincely prince, who guestwise entered with my husband's ring,
This ring, o Collatine! this ring you sent
Is cause of all my woe, your discontent.
I feasted him, then lodged him, and bestowed
The choicest welcome, but in dead of night,
My traitorous guest came armed unto my bed,
Frighted my silent sleep, threatened, and prayed
For entertainment: I despised both.
Which hearing his sharp pointed scimitar,
The tyrant bent against my naked breast,
Alas, I begged my death, but note his tyranny,
He brought with him a torment worse than death
For having murdered me, he swore to kill,
One of my basest grooms and lodge him dead
In my dead arms: then call in testimony
Of my adultery, to make me hated
Even in my death, of husband, father, friends,
Of Rome and all the world: this, this, o princes, ravished and killed me at once,

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Yet comfort lady, I quit thy guilt, for what could
Lucrece do more than a woman? hadst thou died polluted,
By this base scandal, thou hadst wronged thy fame,
and hindered us of a most just revenge.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: What shall we do lords?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Lay your resolute hands upon the sword of Brutus,
Vow and swear, as you hope meed for merit from the gods
Or fear reward for sin, from devils below:
As you are Romans, and esteem your fame
More than your lives all humorous toys set off,
Of madding, singing, smilings, and what else,
Receive your native valours, be yourselves,
And join with Brutus in the just revenge
Of this chaste ravished lady, swear

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We do.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Then with your humours here my grief ends too,
My stain I thus wipe off, call in my sighs,
And in the hope of this revenge, forbear
Even to my death to fall one passionate tear.
Yet lords, that you may crown my innocence,
With our best thoughts, that you may henceforth know,
We are the same in heart we seem in show.
And though I quit my soul of all such sin, the lords whisper
I'll not debar my body punishment:
Let all the world, learn of a Roman dame,
To prize her life less than her honoured fame.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.l: Lucrece?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Wife.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Lady.

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.l: She hath slain herself.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O see yet lords if there be hope of life

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p: She's dead, then turn your funeral tears to fire and indignation, let us now redeem our misspent time, and over take our sloth with hostile expedition, this great lords, this bloody knife, on which her chaste blood flower, shall not from Brutus till some strange revenge fall on the heads of Tarquins.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Now's the time to call their pride to count,
Brutus lead on, we'll follow thee to their confusion.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: By Jove we will, the sprightful youth of Rome,
Tricked up in plumed harness, shall attend
the march of Brutus, whom we here create our general against the Tarquins.

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.l: Be it so.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: We embrace it: now to stir the wrath of Rome,
You, Collatine and good Lucretius,
With eyes yet drowned in tears, bear that chaste body
Into the market place: that horrid object,
Shall kindle them with a most just revenge.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: To see the father and the husband mourn
O'er this chaste dame, that have so well deserved
Of Rome and them, than to infer the pride,
The wrongs and the perpetual tyranny
Of all the Tarquins, Servius, Tullius' death,
And his unnatural usage by that monster
Tullia the Queen all these shall well concur in a combined revenge

sp.speaker: Bru,
sp.l: Lucrece, thy death we'll mourn in glittering arms
And plumed casks: some bear that reverend load,
Unto the forum where our force shall meet
To set upon the Pallas, and expel
This viperous brood from Rome: I know the people
Will gladly embrace our fortunes: Scevola,
Go you and muster powers in Brutus' name.
Valerius, you assist him instantly,
And to the mazed people freely speak the cause of this concourse

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: We go.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: And you dear lord, whose speechless grief is boundless,
Turn all your tears with ours, to wrath and rage,
The hearts of all the Tarquins shall weep blood
Upon the funeral hearse, with whose chaste body,
Honour your arms, and to th'assembled people,
Disclose her innocent wounds: gramercies lords,
sp.stage: A great shout and a flourish with drums and trumpets,
sp.l: That universal shout tells me their words
Are gracious with the people, and their troops
Are ready embattled and expect but us,
To lead their troops, Jove give our fortune's speed,
We'll murder, murder, and base rape shall bleed.

div.stage: Alarum, enter in the fight Tarquin and Tullia flying, pursued by brutus, and the Romans march with drum and colours, Porsenna, aruns. Sextus, Tarquin, and Tullia meets and join with them: to them Brutus, and the Romans with drum and soldiers: they make a stand.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Even thus far tyrant have we dogged thy steps,
Frighting thy frighted fear with horrid steel.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: Lodge in the safety of Porsenna's arms
Now traitor Brutas we dare front thy pride.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Porsenna thar't unworthy of a sceptre,
To shelter pride, lust, rape, and tyranny,
In that proud prince and his confederate sons.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Traitors to heaven, to Tarquin, room and us,
Treason to Kings, doth stretch even to the gods,
And those high gods that take great Rome in charge,
Shall punish your rebellion.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: O devil! Sextus speak not thou of gods,
Not cast those false and feigned eyes to heaven,
Whose rape the furies must torment in hell, of Lucr: Lucrece:

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.l: Her chaste blood sul cries for vengeance to the etherial deities

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.l: O 'twas a foul deed Sextus,

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: And thy shame shall be eternal, and outline her fame,
Say Sextus loved her, was she not a woman,
Ay, and perhaps was willing to be forced,
Must you being private subject dare to ring
Wars loud alarum 'gainst your potent King?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: Brutus therein thou dost forget thyself, and wrongest the glory of thine ancestors, staining thy blood with treason.

sp.speaker: Brut.
sp.l: Tuscan know the consul Brutus is their powerful foe.
Ali Tarquin. Consul?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: I consul, and the powerful hand of Rome
Grasps his imperial sword: the name of King
The tyrant Tarquin's have made odious
Unto this nation: and the general knee,
Of this our warlike people, now low bends
To royal Brutus where the King's name ends.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Now Sextus where's the oracle, when I kissed
my mother earth it plainly did foretell,
My noble virtues should thy sin exceed,
Brutus should sway, and lust-burnt Tarquin bleed

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.p: Now shall the blood of Servius fall, as heavy as a huge mountain on your tyrant heads, o'erwhelming all your glory.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Tullia's guilt shall be by us revenged, that in her pride,
In blood paternal, her rough coach-wheels died.

sp.speaker: Lucre,
sp.l: Your tyrannies,

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Pride,

sp.speaker: Col
sp.l: And my Lucrece fate, shall all be swallowed in this hostile hate.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: O Romulus, thou that first reared yond walls,
In sight of which we stand in thy soft bosom,
Is hanged the nest in which the Tarquins build,
Which in the branches of thy lofty spires,
Tarquin shall perch, or where he once hath stood.
His high built airy shall be drowned in blood,
Alarum then, Brutus by heaven I vow,
My sword shall prove thou ne'er wast mad till now.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Sextus, my madness with your lives expires,
Thy sensual eyes are fixed upon that wall,
Thou ne'er shalt enter, room confines you all.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: A charge then.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: Jove and Tarquin.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: But we, cry a Brutus.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Lucrece, force and victory.

div.stage: Alarum, the romans are beaten of.
Alarum. Enter Brutus, Horatius, Valerius, Scevola, Lucretius, Colatine.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Thou jovial hand hold up thy sceptre high
And let not justice be oppressed with pride,
O you senators leave not room and us,
Grasped in the purple hands of death and ruin, the Tarquins have the best.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Yet stand, my foot is fixed upon this bridge.
Tiber, thy arched streams shall be changed crimson, with
Roman blood, before I trudge form hence.

sp.speaker: Scevol.
sp.l: Brutus retire, for if thou enter Rome,
We are all lost, stand not on valour now,
But save thy people, let's survive this day
To try the fortunes of another field.

sp.speaker: Valer.
sp.l: Break down the bridge, lest the pursuing enemy
Enter with us and take the spoil of Rome.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Then break't behind me, for by heaven I'll grow,
And root my foot as deep as to the centre, before I leave this passage.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.l: Come you're mad.

sp.speaker: Collat.
sp.p: The foe comes on and we in trifling here hazard ourself and people.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Save them all, to make Rome stand, Horatius here will fall.

sp.speaker: Brut
sp.l: We would not lose thee, do not breast thyself
Amongst thousands if thou frontest them thou art winged,
With million swords and darts, and we behind
Must break the bridge of Tiber to save Rome,
Before thee infinits gaze on thy face,
And menace death, the raging streams of Tiber are at thy back to swallow thee.

sp.speaker: Horat.
sp.l: Retire to make Rome live, 'tis death that I desire.

sp.speaker: Brut.
sp.l: Then farewell dead Horatius, think in us
The universal arm of potent Rome
Takes his last leave of thee in this embrace.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Farewell.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Brut.
sp.p: These arches all must down to interdict their passage the town.

div.stage: Alarum, enter Tarquin, Persenna, and Aruns, with their pikes and targetieres.
A noise of knocking down the bridge within.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Soft Tarquin, see a bulwark to this bridge.
You first must pass, the man that enters here
Must make his passage through Horatius' breast,
See with this target do I buckle Rome,
And with this sword defy the puissant army of two great King.

sp.speaker: Porsen.
sp.l: One man to face an host,
Charge soldiers, of full forty thousand Romans,
There's but one daring hand against your host,
to keep you from the sack or spoil of Rome, charge, charge.

div.stage: Aruns. upon them soldiers, enter in several places, Sextus and Valerius above.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: O cowards, slaves, and vassals what not enter?
Was it for this you placed my regiment
Upon a hill, to be the sad spectator
Of such a general cowardice? Tarquin, Aruns,
Porsenna, soldiers, pass, Horatius quickly,
And they behind him will devolve the bridge
And raging Tiber that's impassable,
Your host must swim before you conquer Rome.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Yet stand Horatius, bear but one brunt more
The arched brunt shall sink upon his piles.
And in his fall lift up thy real me to heaven

sp.speaker: Sext.
sp.l: Yet enter.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Dear Horatius, yet stand, and save a million by one powerful hand

div.stage: Alarum and the falling of the bridge.

sp.speaker: Aruns and all.
sp.l: Charge charge, charge.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Degenerate slaves, the bridge is fallen, Rome's lost.
Valer. Horatius thou art stronger than their hosts,
Thy strength is virtue, theirs are idle boasts.
Now save thyself and leap into the waves.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Porsenna, Tarquin, now wade passed your depths,
And enter Rome, I feel my body sink
Beneath my ponderous weight, Rome is preserved,
And now farewell: for he that follows me
Must search the bottom of this raging stream,
Fame with thy golden wings, renown my crest,
And Tiber take me on thy silver breast.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: He's leapt off from the bridge and drowned himself.

sp.speaker: Sext.
sp.l: You are deceived his spirits soars too high
To be choked in with the base element
Of water, lo he swims armed as he was,
Whilst all the army have discharged their arrows.
Of which the shield upon his back stick full.
And hark the suit of all the multitude.
Now welcomes him a land, Horatius' fame
hath checked our armies with a general shame;
But come, to morrow's fortune must restore,
This scandal, which I of the gods implore,

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Then we must find another time fair prince,
To scourge these people, and revenge your wrongs.
For this night I'll betake me to my tent

div.stage: A table and lights in the tent.

sp.speaker: Tarq.
sp.l: And we to ours, to morrow we will renown
Our army with the spoil of a rich-town.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Our secretary.

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Command lights and torches in our tents.
And let a guard ingirt our safety round,
Whilst we debate, of military business: come sit and let's consult.

sp.speaker: Sceu.
sp.l: Horatius, famous for defending Rome.
But we ha' done naught worthy Scevola.
Nor of a roman, I in this disguise
Have passed the army and the puissant guard
Of King Porsenna; this should be his tent
And in good time, now fate direct my strength
Against a King to free great Rome at length.

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.l: O I am slain, treason, treason.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Villain what hast thou done?

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.l: Why slain the King.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: What King?

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.l: Porsenna.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Porsenna lives to see thee tortured,
With plagues more devilish than the plague of hell.

sp.speaker: Sceu.
sp.l: O too rash Matius, hast thou missed thy aim?
And thou base hand that didst direct my poniard
Against a peasant's breast, behold thy error
Thus I will punish, I will give thee freely
Unto the fire, nor will I wear a limb,
That with such rashness shall offend his lord.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: What will the madman do▪

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.l: Porsenna so punish my hand thus, for not killing thee.
Three hundred noble lads beside myself
Have vowed to all the gods that patron Rome,
Thy ruin for supporting tyranny;
And though I fai●e, expect yet every hour,
When some strange fate thy fortunes will devour.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Stay roman, we admire thy constancy,
And scorn of fortune, go return to Rome,
We give thee life, and say the King Porsenna,
Whose life thou seek'st is this honourable,
Pass freely, guard him to the walls of Rome,
And were we not so much engaged to Tarquin,
We would not lift a hand against that nation that breeds such noble spirits.

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.l: Well I go, and for revenge take life even of my foe.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Conduct him safely, what 300 gallants
Sworn to our death, and all resolved like him!
We must be provident, to morrow's fortune
We'll prove for Tarquin, if they fail our hopes,
Peace shall be made with Rome, but first our secretary,
Shall have his due rights of funeral, than our shield
We must address next for to morrow's field.

div.stage: Enter Brutus, Horatius, Valerius, collainte, Lucretius marching.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: By thee we are consul, and still govern Rome,
Which but for thee, had been despoiled and ta'en,
Made a confused heap of men and stones,
Swimming in blood and slaughter, dear Horatius
Thy noble picture shall be carved in brass,
And fixed for thy perpetual memory in our high capitol.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Great consul thanks, but leaving this let's march out of the city.
And once more bid them battle on the plains.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: This day my soul divines we shall live free
From all the furious Tarquins: but where's Scaevola? we see not him today.
Here lords behold me handless as you see,
the cause I missed Porsenna in his tent,
And in his stead killed but his secretary.
The mazed King when he beheld me punish
My rash mistake, with loss of my right hand
Unbegged and almost scorned he gave me life,
Which I had then refused, but in desire to venge fair Lucrece
Rape.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Dear Scevola thou hast exceeded us in our resolve,
But will the Tarquins give us present battle?

sp.speaker: Sceu.
sp.p: That may ye hear, the skirmish is begun already twixt the horse.

sp.speaker: Lucre.
sp.l: Then noble consul lead our main battle on.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: O Jove this day balance our cause, and let the innocent blood
Of rape stained Lucrece crown with death and horror
The heads of all the Tarquins, see this day
In her cause do we consecrate our lives,
And in defence of justice now march on:
I hear their martial music, be our shock
As terrible as are the meeting clouds
That break in thunder, yet our hopes are fair,
And this rough charge shall all our hopes repair.

sp.speaker: P●rsenna.
sp.l: Yet grow our lofty plumes unflagged with blood,
And yet sweet pleasure wantons in the air, how goes the battle Aruns?

sp.speaker: Aruns.
sp.p: 'Tis even balanced, I interchanged with Brutus' hand to hand, a dangerous encounter both are wounded, and had not the rude press divided us, one had dropped down to earth.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: 'Twas bravely fought, I saw the King your father free his person from thousand Romans that begird his state, where flying arrows thick as atoms hung about his ears.

sp.speaker: Aruns.
sp.l: I hope a glorious day, come tuscan King, let's on then.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Aruns stay that sword that late did drink the consul's blood
Must with his keen fang tire upon my flesh, or this on mine.

sp.speaker: Aruns.
sp.p: It spared the consul's life to end thy days in a more glorious strife.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: I stand against thee Tuscan.

sp.speaker: P●rs.
sp.l: I for thee.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Where ere I find a Tarquin, he's for me.

div.stage: Alarum, fight, Aruns slain, Porsenna expulsed.
div.p: Alarum, enter Tarquin with an arrow in his breast, Tullia with him, pursued by Collatine, Lucretius, Scevola.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: Fair Tullia leave me, save thy life by flight,
Since mine is desperate, behold I am wounded
Even to the death, there stays within my tent
A winged jennet, mount his back and fly,
Live to revenge my death since I must die.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.l: Had I the heart to tread upon the bulk
Of my dead father, and to see him slaughtered,
Only for love of Tarquin and a crown,
And shall I fear death more than loss of both?
No this is Tullia's fame, rather than fly
From Tarquin, amongst a thousand swords she'll die.

sp.speaker: All,
sp.l: Hew them to pieces both.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: My Tullia save, and o'er my caitiff head those meteors wave.

sp.speaker: Colla.
sp.l: Let Tullia yield then.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.l: Yield me cuckold no mercy, I scorn let me the danger know.

sp.speaker: Sceu.
sp.l: Upon them then.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.l: Let's bring them to their fate,
And let them perish in the people's hate.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.l: Fear not, I'll back thee husband.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: But for thee, sweet were the hand that this charged soul could free.
Life I despise, let noble Sextus stand
To avenge our death, even till these vitals end,
Scorning my own, this life will I defend.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.l: And I'll sweet Tarquin to my power guard thine,
Come on you slaves and make this earth divine.

sp.speaker: Brut.
sp.l: Aruns this crimson favour for thy sake,
I'll wear upon my forehead masked with blood
Till all the moistures in the Tarquins veins
be spilt upon the earth and leave thy body
As dry as the parched summer, burned and scorched with the canicular stars.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Aruns lies dead by this bright sword that's here about his head.

sp.speaker: Colla.
sp.p: And see great consul, where the pride of Rome lies sunk and fallen.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.p: Besides him lies the Queen mangled and hewed amongst the Roman soldièrs.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: Lift up their slaughtered bodies, help to rear them against this hill in view of all the camp, this sight will be a terror to the so, and make them yield or fly.

sp.speaker: Brut.
sp.l: But where's the ravisher, injurious Sextus that we see not him?

sp.speaker: Sext.
sp.l: Through broken spears, cracked swords, unbowelled steeds
Flawed armours, mangled limbs, and battered casks,
Knee deep in blood, I ha' pierced the Roman host to be my father's rescue.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: 'Tis too late, his mounting pride's sunk in the people's hate.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: My father, mother, brother, fortune now,
I do defy thee, I expose myself,
To horrid danger, safety I despise,
I dare the worst of peril I am bound.
On till this pile of flesh be all one wound,

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: Begird him lord, this is the ravisher.
There's no revenge for Lucrece till he fall.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Cease Sextus then.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Sextus defies you all, yet will you give me language ere I die:

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Say on.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: 'Tis not for mercy, for I scorn that life
That's given by any, and the more to add
To your immense unmeasurable hate,
I was the spur unto my father's pride,
'Twas I that awed the princes of the land,
That made thee Brutus' mad, these discontents,
I ravished the chaste Lucrece, Sextus I,
The daughter and thy wife, Brutus thy cousin.
Allied indeed to all, 'twas for my rape,
her constant hand ripped up her innocent breast, 'twas Sextus did all this.
Which I'll revenge.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Leave that to me.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.l: Old as I am I'll do't.

sp.speaker: Scenol.
sp.p: I have one hand yet left, of strength enough to kill a ravisher.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Come all at once, I all: yet hear me Brutus, thou art honorable.
And my words tend to thee: my father died
By many hands, what's he amongst you can challenge
The lest I smallest honour in his death?
If I be killed amongst this hostile throng
The poorest snaky soldier well may claim
As much renown in royal Sextus' death,
As Brutus, thou, or thou Horatius.
I am to die, and more than die I cannot,
Rob not yourselves of honour in my death.
When the two mightiest spirits of Greece and Troy
Tugged for the mastery, Hector and Achilles,
Had puissant Hector by Achilles' hand,
Died in a single monomachy Achilles,
Had been the worthy, but being slain by odds,
The poorest Myrmidon had as much honour
As saint Achilles in the Trojans death.

sp.speaker: Br●t.
sp.l: Hadst thou not done a deed so execrable,
That gods and men abhor, I'd love thee Sextus,
And hug thee for this challenge breathed so freely:
Behold, I stand for Rome as general,
Thou of the Tarquins dost alone survive,
The head of all these garboils the chief actor
Of that black sin which we chastise by arms.
Brave Romans with your bright swords be our lists
And ring us in none dare to offend the prince
By the least touch lest he incur our wrath:
This honour do your consul, that his hand
May punish this arch mischief, that the times
Succeeding may of Brutus thus much tell,
by him pride, lust, and all the Tarquins fell.

sp.speaker: Sext.
sp.l: To ravish Lucrece cuckold Collatine:
And spill the chastest blood that ever ran,
In any matrons veins, repents me not
So much as to ha' wronged a gentleman
So noble as the consul in this strife.
Brutus be bold, thou fightest with one scorns life.

sp.speaker: Brut.
sp.l: And thou with one that less than his renown
Prizeth his blood or Rome's imperial crown

div.stage: Alarum, a fierce fight with sword and target, then after pa●se and breath.

sp.speaker: Brut.
sp.l: Sextus stand fair, much honour shall I win
To revenge Lucrece, and chastise thy sin.

sp.speaker: Sext●
sp.l: I repent nothing, may I live or die,
Though my blood fall, my spirit shall mount on high.

div.stage: Alarum, fight with single swords, and being deadly wounded and panting for breath making a stroke at each together with their gauntlets they fall.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Both slain: o noble Brutus this thy fame
To after ages shall survive, thy body
Shall have a fair and gorgeous sepulchre:
For whom the matrons shall in funeral black
Mourn twelve sad moons, thou that first governed Rome,
And swayed the people by a consul's name.
These bodies of the Tarquins we'll commit
Unto the funeral pile: you Collatine
Shall succeed Brutus, in the consul's place.
Whom with this laurel wreath we here relate
Such is the people's voice, accept it then.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: We do, and may our power so just appear
Rome may have peace, both with our love and fear.
But soft, what march is this?

div.stage: Flourish Porsenna, drum, Collatine and soldiers

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: The Tuscan King, seeing the Tarquins slain.
Thus armed and battled offers peace to Rome.
To confirm which, we'll give you present hostage
If you deny, we'll stand upon our guard,
and by the force of arms, maintain our own

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: After so much effusion and large waste
Of Roman blood the name of peace is welcome,
Since of the Tarquins none remain in Rome.
And Lucrece rape is now revenged at full.
'Twere good to entertain Porsenna's league.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Col. Porsenna we embrace whose royal presence.
Shall grace the consul to the funeral pile.
March on to Rome, Jove be our guard and guide,
That hath in us venged rape and punished pride.
